You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: credit continued to be available to most businesses, households, and municipalities.\n                "}]

If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in addition, members agreed to continue to reduce the federal reserve's holdings of treasury securities and agency debt and agency mortgage‑backed securities.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",

If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. 2025-05-04 00:12:59,334 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Federal Reserve System\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: other forward-looking indicators, such as subdued readings from surveys of business conditions and capital spending plans, also pointed toward roughly flat real expenditures for business equipment in the near term.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:12:59,334 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates subdued business conditions and flat real expenditures, suggesting a slowing economy, which may require expansionary monetary policy."
}

If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in light of the improved conditions, the staff proposed that the desk no longer be required to increase agency cmbs holdings or reinvest principal payments for agency cmbs.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The proposal to stop increasing agency CMBS holdings or reinvesting principal payments suggests a more accommodative monetary policy stance, indicating a dovish tone."
}

If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. continued to hold very high levels of cash.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the information reviewed at this meeting suggested that, before the landfall of hurricane katrina on the gulf coast, expansion of economic activity had been solid, led by robust gains in housing and buoyant consumer spending.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: more fundamentally, however, the income and wealth effects that were boosting household expenditures generally should help to sustain a perhaps somewhat diminished but still high level of homebuilding activity for a while, despite higher mortgage financing costs.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the past year, businesses had added to inventories at a rate that exceeded the rise in final sales, and somewhat reduced accumulation to a pace more in line with that of final sales was seen as a reasonable expectation.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:13:23,689 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the adjustment of inventory accumulation to match final sales, without indicating any change in inflation or unemployment rates, thus maintaining a neutral stance."

\\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: participants noted strong recent payroll growth, while the unemployment rate remained low.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions strong payroll growth and a low unemployment rate, indicating a strong economy, which may lead to inflation concerns and tighter monetary policy."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2.
